required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Brain Training Tools With Physical Practice on Motor Learning
clinical_study.official_title: Assessment of the Effects of Brain Training Tools in Combination With Physical Practice on the Acquisition of Different Motor Tasks: a Randomised Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates the influence of motor imagery and action observation in combination with physical practice on motor learning

primary_outcome.measure: Hit ratio in a manual skill test
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from hit ratio in a manual skill at 1 week
primary_outcome.description: This main variable will be composed by the learning of a sequence of digital movements.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from hit ratio in free throws at 1 week
primary_outcome.description: The percentage of successful basketball shots in different positions will be counted.

Subjects shall place their feet shoulder width apart and their toes in a line on the floor. The subjects will then make a horizontal leap forward, where they are allowed to swing their arms along a tape measure attached to the floor.

intervention.description: This group will perform motor imagery training in combination with physical practice on motor learning of different motor tasks.
This group will perform motor imagery training by doubling the intervention time to the motor imagery group in combination with physical practice on motor learning of various motor tasks.
This group will perform action observation training in combination with physical practice on motor learning of various motor tasks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- asymptomatic subjects
- men and women between 18 and 65 years of age
- participants with no systemic, neurological, cognitive or psychological disease.
Exclusion Criteria:
- underage participants
- presence of systemic pathology, pain and/or weakness that prevents the protocol
- participants who have undergone an operation in the spine.

overall_contact.last_name: Roy A La Tocuhe, physiotherapist PhD
